Review A review: Multi-hierarchy design strategy of electrocatalysts for energy molecule conversion Chenjia Liang Rurong Liu Ruiyao Zhao Xiaoxia Hou Yingxuan Zhao Jie Yang Tao Wang Teng Chen ⁎ Weiping Ding ⁎ Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, Jiangsu, China Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University Nanjing Jiangsu 210023 China Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The roles of multi-hierarchy design for electrocatalyst from active centers, novel supports, and reaction microenvironment are reviewed and the development of electrocatalyst aimed at solving industrial catalytic problems is discussed. Under the new energy resource structure, electrocatalysts are key materials for the development of proton membrane fuel cells, electrolysis of aquatic hydrogen devices, and carbon dioxide reduction equipment, to address energy shortages and even environmental pollution issues. Although controlling the morphology or doping with heteroatoms for catalyst active centers have accelerated the reaction rate, it is difficult to solve the problems of multiple by-products, and poor stability of catalytic sites. From this, it will be seen that single regulation of metal active centers is difficult to comprehensively solve application problems. Orderly assembly and coordination of catalyst multi-hierarchy structures at the mesoscale above the nanometer level probably be more reasonable strategies, and numerous studies in thermal catalysis have supported this viewpoint. This article reviews the multi-hierarchy design of electrocatalyst active centers, high-energy supports, and peripheral structures in recent years, providing unconventional inspiration about electrocatalyst creation, which perhaps serves as a simple tutorial of electrocatalysis exploration for abecedarian. Keywords Novel electrocatalysts Energy molecular conversion Multi-hierarchy design strategy 1 Introduction With the rapid increase in limited fossil fuel consumption, resulting in serious air pollution and energy shortages, developing clean and sustainable energy conversion device has become an urgent responsibility [1–5]. Hydrogen energy (the energy density of 120 MJ kg−1 for hydrogen is far more than gasoline with 44 MJ kg−1) is considered one of the most promising clean energy sources in the 21st century [6–8]. With this regard, proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), electrochemical water splitting and so forth have been extensively designed as next-generation conversion materials technology in new energy structure [9–11], which involve the electrocatalytic conversion of small molecules such as hydrogen, oxygen, water, low-carbon alcohol, and even carbon dioxide. However, the molecules as a medium to complete the mutual conversion of electrical and chemical energy are not an uncomplicated process [4,12,13]. It usually requires overcoming huge energy barriers, slow reaction kinetics, and even reducing low-value side reactions [14]. Taking PEMFCs as an example, in the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), the adsorption as well as desorption processes of OH*/OOH* species on metal catalytic sites seriously affect the reaction efficiency [15,16]; in the process of anodic alcohol oxidation, slow step-by-step dehydrogenation process of methanol after adsorption on platinum surface and CO* species poisoning the active site causes great obstacles to the reaction [9,17]. In terms of CO2 reduction (CO2RR), a significant hydrogen evolution process occurs within the reaction potential range, which seriously decreases the Faraday efficiency of high value-added products [18–20]. In the above reactions, the key to achieving efficient conversion, between intramolecular chemical and electrical energy, is the design and preparation of the remarkable electrocatalyst structure. In the development history of heterogeneous catalysis for more than 100 years, the understanding of catalytic reaction process has developed from ambiguity to precision, which provides a foundation for the multi-hierarchy design of catalysts [21–24]. Following the principle of imitation and learning from the master of natural catalysis: inartificial enzymes, a series of well-designed catalysts have been developed to solve important industrial problems. Analogous to the structure–activity relationship between the peripheral structure and active center of methane monooxygenase, bringing in organic phosphate to regulate the Fe reaction center will achieve the air oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde [25–27]; the Cu NPs with high-density step sites, surrounded by Na-Beta zeolite, will achieve 100% selectivity for ethanol (∼12,000 mL gcat −1−h−1), an efficient structure for CO2* coupling [28]; the successful preparation of γ-alumina with high-energy external surfaces such as 111 facets loading CrO x will be explored for semihydrogenation of acetylene, an economically friendly alternative relative to commercial precious Pd catalysts [29]. By analyzing the above breakthrough catalysts, it is easy to identify that the composition of catalysts will be defined as active sites, supports, and peripheral structures (micro-environment) [30]. Similarly, the mutual cooperation of different constituents will be a feasible path for electrocatalysts development. For instance, the researchers have designed iron porphyrin microenvironment in imitation of horseradish peroxidase to effectively improve ORR performance and 4-electron process selectivity [31], indicating enzyme-like design for catalysts are also suitable for improving electrocatalytic processes. This article will review the multi-hierarchy and rational design of advanced electrocatalysts, by comprehensively considering three parts: active center, high-energy support, and peripheral structure, for key reactions in new-energy systems such as ORR, MOR, HER, CO2RR, and so on. The design and coordination of the above three components will achieve unparalleled effects in the unique catalytic system compared to a single module. This review focuses more on the extraordinary design ideas of the advance catalysts, rather than the new-type materials only. 2 The unique active center structure Since the concept of catalyst was proposed forward in 1863, researchers’ cognitive accuracy of actives site for catalysis process has been continuously improved, with more accurate spectroscopic equipment. Pt, Pd, Ru and other precious metals are key catalysis sites for energy conversion reactions such as ORR and HER, but the slow surface reaction kinetics and high costs will not be ignored, which affect the industrial application of electrocatalytic reaction devices [32,33]. Improving the intrinsic activity and increasing the exposure area of metal sites in the reaction system are direct means to improve electrocatalytic efficiency [34]. On the side, the basic relationship between the surface electronic structure of a given catalyst and the catalytic activity of the catalyst ORR is described as “volcano-type” [35]. The optimal activity is the balance between the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates and the available reaction sites. 2.1 Diverse morphologies for active site In order to increase the mass activity of platinum-group sites, some platinum-group nanomaterials with variant size [36], composition [37], and topological structure [38–40] have been designed and developed (Fig. 1 a), for example, Pd@Pt core–shell concave decahedra [41], Pt–Ni octahedral [42], Mo–Pt3Ni octahedral nanocrystals [43], J-PtNWs [38], PtPb hexagonal nanoplates [37], 3D Pt3Ni nanoframes [44], tailoring amorphous PdCu nanostructures [45] and even high entropy alloy [46,47]. The regulation of topological structure reduces the amount of precious metals used, enhances reaction activity, and improves the ability to resist poisoning, significantly optimized compared to traditional metal–carbon electrocatalysts for energy conversion [48]. For atomically ordered design active center, the intermetallic nanoparticles have aroused the attention of researchers, on account of electronic properties and near-surface atomic arrangements which influence the activity, selectivity, and stability [49–51]. Yang et al. [52] prepared platinum intermetallic compounds with an average diameter of less than 5 nm by the strong interaction between platinum and sulfur inhibited metal sintering up to 1000 °C (Fig. 1b). In addition, a small nanoparticle intermetallic reservoir composed of 46 kinds of platinum and 16 other metal elements was synthesized. The formation and action mechanism are revealed and the intermetallic alloys achieve high activity of 1.3–1.8 A mgPt −1 in PEMFCs, which confirms the application prospect of intermetallic alloys in the field of electrocatalysis. 2.2 Single metal center design With the improvement of characterization methods and synthesis means, researchers are constantly approaching the atomic scale in the development of active centers for electrocatalytic small molecule conversion (Fig. 2 a) [53,54]. In 1964, Jasinski [55] found that cobalt phthalocyanine could catalyze the oxygen reduction reaction at the cathode of fuel cells. Sandstede et al. [56] reported that all these macrocyclic compounds with metal centers and N4 coordination had ORR catalytic activity, and the activity was closely related to the type of metal. What’s more, Yeager et al. [57] found that ORR catalysts with high activity can be obtained only by calcination of appropriate metal sources, nitrogen-containing polymers and carbon sources. Since Zhang group [58] proposed monatomic catalyst in 2011, it has been widely used in thermal, optical, electric and other catalytic fields, becoming a research hotspot. Single atom catalysts are characterized by high atomic utilization rate, isolated active sites, the ability to accurately construct and so on [59–61]. In 2016, Li group [60] introduced Zn as a “fence” to expand the distance of adjacent Co atoms in space to produce Co SAs/N-C without aggregation of Co atoms (Fig. 2b), of which half-wave potentials (0.881 V) for ORR was more positive than that of Pt/C (0.811 V). In 2020, a general host-guest strategy synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon-iridium monoatomic catalyst was reported, and a variety of metallic monoatomic catalysts were developed on nitrogen-doped carbon (M1/CN, M = Pt, Ir, Pt, Pd, Ru, Mo, Ga, Cu, Ni, Mn) (Fig. 2c) [62]. The basic process is to prepare metal SACs on nitrogen-doped carbon, using porous metal–organic frames (MOFs) as hosts to capture metal precursors in situ in the cage during the crystallization of MOF. Then, the metal precursor@MOF composite was pyrolyzed at high temperature, and the metal monatom was fixed on the nitrogen-doped carbon derived from MOF, where Ir1/CN showed high activity to electrocatalytic formic acid oxidation and high resistance to CO toxicity. These methods and strategies are also widely used by other researchers for renewable energy conversions [63–66]. Additionally, Wu et al. [67] regulated the microenvironment of FeN4 site, transforming the active center from defect-rich pyrrolic N-coordinated, high activity and low stability, to pyridinic N-coordinated, high stability and moderate activity (Fig. 1d). The activity of Fe-AC-CVD on MEA losted only 30 mV at 0.8 A cm−2 and 21 mW cm−2 (3.9%) of peak power density after the accelerated stress tests, meeting the challenging DOE stability target for PEMFC cathode catalysts. However, random distribution of metal centers in M−N x C materials prepared by pyrolysis MOFs. A large number of active sites are located inside the frameworks, making it difficult to come into contact with reactant molecules during the reaction and resulting in a decrease in the actual utilization rate of atoms. For another hand, the production cost and yield of MOFs also limit the large-scale and industrial application of M−N x C materials. For overcoming the existing problems of design M−N x sites at the present stage, our group developed a surface conditioning strategy [68], in order to synthesize high homogeneity Cu-N x sites preferentially exposed on nitrogen-fixing carbon nanosheets, thus enabling the catalytic performance to be described by active surface area. High homogeneity Cu-N x sites were synthesized by carbonizing glycylurea and depositing on copper surface. During the acid treatment process for effectively removing Cu bulk, the Cu-N x coordination structure is exposed simultaneously (Fig. 3 a). Due to the characteristic of surface dispersion of active site, the current density at the initial stage of ORR is in accordance with the density of the active site (Fig. 3b). The interference of N-doped carbon is negligible because it presents a large ECSA of 70.94 F g−1 but a small current density of −0.084 g−1 at 0.86 V. Therefore, a linear relationship can be established where the best fitness occurs at 0.86 V due to the medium equivalent of the current density. The normalized ECSA activities of CuG-y catalysts at 0.88, 0.87 and 0.86 V were 17.6, 32.5 and 60.1 mA F−1, respectively. In other words, there is a linear relationship between the current density and the electrochemical active area. The establishment of this relationship not only confirms that the Cu-N x site is the main reaction center of ORR activity from an experimental perspective, but also shows that the Cu-N x sites prepared by this method are highly homogeneous, and all of them are surface dispersed and participate in the catalysis. Compare with the heat treatment of metal organic structures, more atoms can be exposed on the surface to become veritable active centers, improve the utilization rate of actual atoms, and deepen the understanding of structure–activity relationship, which will provide more references for the construction of unexpectable electrocatalytic centers for ORR and even CO2RR. Mechanochemical synthesis is a unique technique that can use the mechanical energy produced by collisions to create high energy or defect sites by breaking or combining chemical bonds [69–72], which has been used by many researchers to prepare single atoms [73,74]. In order to promote the universality of mechanical ball milling method, our group extend the use of mechanical ball milling method, assisted by high temperature, namely, thermomechanical chemical synthesis (HMCS), for simple and extensive preparation of electrocatalysts with metal sites fixed on carbon materials. A series of single transition metal (Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn), anchored by N-doping carbon, were obtained by HMCS [75] (Fig. 3c). The loading capacity of each metal is shown in Fig. 3(d). The method has the following advantages: (1) The outermost layer has a high metal content, which is a unique metal part formed by collision with mechanical energy; (2) Avoiding annealing at high temperature, can retain some unique active sites on the material; (3) Convenient for mass production. FeNCHM has excellent catalytic performance on ORR, with E 1/2 of 0.85 V (vs. RHE), 70 mV surpassing NC and comparable to commercial Pt/C, as well as also shows excellent performance in zinc-air batteries. This provides a feasible approach for the industrial production of highly uniform and surface dispersed single metal site for electrocatalysis active centers. Li et al. [76] utilized a chemical vapor deposition strategy and constructed Fe-N-C to achieve surface dispersion in H2-O2 proton exchange membrane fuel cells at 1.0 bar and 80 °C. This catalyst provided unprecedented excellent oxygen reduction reactivity (33 mA cm−2, 0.90 V). In addition, to solve the problem of low active site density, Wan et al. [77] reported a class of concave Fe-N-C monoatomic catalysts with enhanced surface area and mesopore, which achieved high catalytic activity and demonstrated high atomic utilization under working conditions. Liu et al. [78] proposed a simple and scalable method for the preparation of Fe2+ doped ZIF-8, which can be further pyrolyzed into Fe-N-C to achieve the macropreparation of ZIF-8-based single atoms by mechanochemical means. These breakthroughs enabled industrial applications of single-atom catalysts. In the past five years of researches, M−N x sites, so-called single-atom, studies have focused on D-block transition metals (TMs), which typically have partially filled D-bands across the Fermi level. P-block metal with closed D-shell (d10 electron configuration) [79], such as Bi, Sb and so on, surface catalytic reactivity of main group element is generally inhibited and therefore rarely explored, on account of the fact that it is difficult to introduce main-group elements with significant atomic ratios through the design and pyrolysis of MOFs [80–84]. The new approach mentioned above may be a feasible way to break through the design of active site of P-block metals, coordination with N x . The diverse valence-state changes of the main group elements may play unexpected roles in unexplored electrocatalytic processes. 3 The novel supporter design to anchor active site Pt has shown excellent catalytic performance in electrocatalytic reactions, but due to the low natural abundance and the high price of Pt, researchers have worked to reduce the Pt loading or develop lower-cost high-performance electrocatalysts to replace Pt. Although M−N x C materials have shown excellent performance in three-electrode system, the decrease in metal/carbon ratio leads to an increase in the thickness of the catalytic layer, which affects mass and electron transfer as well as significantly affects the application of M−N x C materials on membrane electrodes [85–87]. The multi-metal composite heterostructure will be an ideal solution that may combine the specific properties of each group element and also take advantage of the synergistic and electronic effects between heterogeneous atoms to improve the catalytic activity [88]. Researchers have initially explored the use of electronic effects to moderate the binding energy of reaction intermediates at the active site and accordingly optimize their intrinsic activity through cation/anion doping or the construction of nano heterojunctions. The concept of electron metal-support interaction (EMSI) was introduced by Campbell [89], suggesting that the interaction between the carrier and the metal can shift the d-band center energy, which in turn adjusts the adsorption of reaction intermediates and affects the chemical properties and catalytic performance [90]. Specific functional groups and spatial structure of the support surface can play the role of anchoring the catalyst atoms, and also act as a co-catalyst to regulate the electron distribution, due to EMSI, in the catalytic reaction, which in turn can regulate the density of metal states or surface electron-cloud for the loaded metal and achieve the goal of improving the electrocatalytic activity, defined as “High energy support” [91–93]. So far, the research on the synthesis, characterization, and application of various types of supports has been summarized systematically, while the research on their design ideas still lacks generalization [94–96]. The rational regulatory ideas are vital for regulating the surface electronic properties, constructing efficient heterogeneous structures, and exploring the intrinsic conformational relationships, which are essential for further guiding the synthesis of high-performance catalytic materials. 3.1 The supports design for electron-rich state Alloying of Pt with a TM to form Pt- or core-shell bimetallic nanoalloys is a common scheme at this stage to prepare high-performance and low-loading electrocatalytic materials [97,98], in which the d-band center of Pt is down-shifted by the internal transition metal through electronic or strain effects modulation, leading to a weakening of the binding energy of Pt to oxygen intermediate species and thus improving the ORR performance of the material. However, the leaching of TMs inside such materials is often unavoidable, and thus there is often a stability problem [99]. Our group proposed that ideal highly durable and active catalysts will be constructed by constructing Pt/CN x /Ni ternary heterostructures that combine rich-electron Pt and Ni through two to three CN x layers to improve ORR activity by electron transfer according to the Mott-Schottky rule while avoiding the dissolution of internal transition metals by forming a dense conductive shell (Fig. 4 a) [100]. Half-wave potential of Pt/CN x /Ni for ORR reaches 0.886 V (vs. RHE.) and the mass activity reached 780% of that of commercial Pt/C (Fig. 4b). XRD results confirm the effective separation of Ni and Pt. ADT test results show that Pt/CN x /Ni has only a negative shift of 17 mV in the half-wave potential after 50,000 cycles, which is 73% less than that of Pt/C. Such electron regulation means will be used not only in the field of electrocatalysis but also in the field of thermal catalysis. Bao group [101] also report loading Pt NPs on graphene encapsulating CoNi nanoalloys for CO oxidation in an oxygen-rich environment, achieving near 100% CO conversion at room temperature. Such an electron modulation method in a ternary heterostructure provides researchers with a new idea to improve the electrocatalytic performance of transition metal phosphides with similar properties to platinum group metals, which is an effective alternative to platinum group metals. Based on the above work, our group also tried to introduce this ternary heterostructure into non-Platinum group metal composites and synthesized a CoP/CN/Ni ternary heterostructure catalyst for both HER and ORR reactions, which achieved a remarkable breakthrough [102]. Electrons on Ni NPs were transferred to the outer CoP through the CN shell (Fig. 4c), and this electron modulation improved the initial slow reaction kinetics of CoP, the overpotential in HER decreased significantly relative to CoP under both acidic and basic conditions, and showed ORR activity similar to Pt/C in 0.1 M KOH (Fig. 4d). More interestingly, the carriers can not only play the role of electron transfer. Through a unique Co-modified/N-C/Pt design, Sun et al. [103] discovered that the Co-N-C carriers were able to modulate the electrons while the Co single atom introduced in the N-doped carbon substrate was able to anchor the Pt NPs at the same time. Co atoms anchored on the N-C not only significantly enhanced the MOR activity of Pt, but also the unique two-atom center synergy also significantly enhances the CO-durability of the Pt active site (Fig. 4e). Similarly, Qiu group [104] prepared PtCo/Co-N-C for ORR and EOR, which had a lower overpotential than PtCo/N-C in ORR. A stable open-circuit voltage of 0.6 V was achieved when applied as a flexible all-solid-state direct ethanol fuel cell for testing, which has a promising application prospect. Wei et al. [105] utilized electron-rich TiO2 confined Ru clusters to exhibit unforeseen HOR catalytic activity in environments containing CO. Based on electron transfer, the high occupancy state of Ru 4d orbitals increases reaction activity, and solves the dissolution problem of Ru in acidic systems. 3.2 The supports design for electron-moderate state The electron-donor regulation for catalytic center has made a major breakthrough in the ORR, MOR and even HOR processes, but too strong electronic density effect may not be appropriate in all electrocatalytic process. In addition to focusing on the ability to increase the reactivity of the catalyst by internal transition metal transfer through the carrier to the platinum group metals, researchers often focus on the Faraday efficiency of the desired product. Optimal catalysis occurs when interactions between the catalyst and substrate are of intermediate strength, thus an ideal electrocatalyst should interact neither too strongly nor too weakly with the adsorbed intermediates [106]. Depending on the number of electrons transferred during the reaction, CO2RR can yield up to 16 different gaseous and liquid products [107], thus reaction selectivity is a major focus of research. Our group synthesized CoO/CN (electron-deficient state) as an efficient formic acid selective CO2RR catalyst and CoO/CN/Ni (electron-moderate state) as an efficient methanol selective CO2RR catalyst, where the electron donation of CoO/CN/Ni from nickel may compensate for the attraction of electrons from CN layer to Co species and retain moderate electron cloud density of cobalt species, suitable to 6-electron process for producing methanol (Fig. 5 a) [108]. This is a characteristic case that the product selectivity is significantly changed, by adjusting the electronic density states of the active site. The well-designed catalyst presents a remarkable Faraday efficiency of 70.7% to methanol in CO2RR (Fig. 5b). What’s more, CoO/CN/Ni not only improves its electrocatalytic activity for methanol selectivity but also inhibits HER, reflecting the importance of the inner TMs and electron modulation for the Co element. On this basis, the subtle modulation of electronic properties of platinum by Cu-N x support is reported according to the volcanic curve of suitable metal centers describing high catalytic activity, and the electronic properties of metals are finely regulated by the support, additional atomic Cu donates electrons and mitigate the electronic depletion of Pt caused by N dopant, achieving efficient electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance (Fig. 5c) [109]. The proto-evolutionary response of overpotential is only 20 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5d), which is better than commercial Pt/C. At 50 mV, the mass activity reached 40.1 A mgPt −1, which was significantly better than that of Pt/C and control samples without copper. Such adjustments provide with a promising method to guide the formation of ideal products, the design of electron transfer between metal and support, based on the adsorption energy of active site and reaction intermediate, may be the next research hotspot focus. 4 The micro-environment adjustment for boosting and protecting active sites Although researchers have developed the ultrafine nanoparticles with extraordinary specific activity for energy molecular conversion in the past few decades, the nanoscale catalysts mentioned above are usually prone to substantial size growth through either an Ostwald ripening process and dissolution in a rich-proton environment, resulting in the decrease of ECSA and MA, significantly [2,110]. In addition, the dissolving out metal ions, under membrane electrode conditions, will destroy the proton channels in the catalytic layer and proton membrane, which increases the internal resistance of the electrochemical conversion device, irreversibly [111,112]. Especially, for proton membrane fuel cells, researchers currently pursue to cut down platinum usage without reducing output power, which requires a significant increase in the turnover frequency (TOF) of H2 and O2 on the catalyst surface, further increasing the possibility of platinum dissolution. Recently, Shao group [113] proved the Fe-N-C as support will attenuate the loss of Pt in acidic electrolytes by in situ ICP-MS, but the dissolution of Fe ions cannot be avoided. Compared to directly changing the active center, the regulation of microenvironment or peripheral structures, a wider space for catalyst design, will alter the diffusion of substance for, adjust the electronic state of the active center, and stabilize the active center, improving high value-added product selectivity, TOF and operation life. The impact of microenvironment on the reaction center has a series of typical cases in thermo-catalysis process (e.g., CO x hydrogenation [28,114], nitrobenzene reduction [115–118] and even toluene oxidation [25–27]), which may also be the design mentality of electrocatalysts. Regulation of the microenvironment for reaction center may be one of the most effective strategies for stabilizing the active site in harsh environments. What’s more, the special electronic effect and introduced functional groups of the peripheral structure may further enhance the catalytic activity of the key site in electrochemical process. 4.1 Creating graphitized peripheral structure Encapsulating nanoparticles into porous, conductive, and sub-nm scale protective layers is a novel strategy for reducing the corrosion, agglomeration and poisoning of active sites [119,120]. To address the instability of intermetallic compounds in acidic environments, Sung et al. [121] developed a novel synthetic means to obtain highly loaded L10-FePt NPs (∼37 wt%) protected by graphitized shells (<1.5 nm) in Fig. 6 (a). After ADT test, the ECSA, MA and SA of FePt/rGO all remain satisfactory level, indicating there was no significant change in the ordered FePt alloy reaction centers under the protection of peripheral structures during rough environmental testing (Fig. 6b). Moreover, nitrogen-doped carbon shells by pyrolyzation of thin layer polydopamine, an uncomplicated method to scale production, also made available for to protect FeP [122], a base metal sites, for HER in acid, showing a low overpotential of 71 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In Fig. 6(c and d), Huang et al. [123] designed a graphene nanopockets encapsulated ultrafine PtCo, to further avoid the possibility of metal agglomeration during carbonization, not only ensuring electrochemical accessibility, but also restricting catalyst coalescence, oxidative dissolution, and Ostwald ripening process, a potential loss of only 23.5 mV at 0.8 A cm−2 and a MA retention of 66% after stability testing (achieving EOL target). Yoo group [124] also developed a hydrogen etching strategy for the secondary modification of peripheral structure to create different exposed metal surface areas, at the sub-nm level without changing the particle size. By adjusting the etching degree through changes in hydrogen concentration, a balance point between stability and activity of PtFe@C will be found. Due to the convenience of storage and transportation, methanol is the best substitute for hydrogen gas in the anode of fuel cells, but the development of DMFCs is limited by the slow reaction kinetics of methanol on platinum surface and the deactivation of active centers by CO* intermediates [125–127]. In order to break through the limitations of methanol electro-oxidation, we constructed a nest-type Zn-N x -C peripheral framework structure around PtZnδ NPs, supported on XC-72R, through anchor and self-assembly strategy (Fig. 6e) [128]. Under the electron transfer and physical limitations of the ZNC nest, the PtZnδ site not only exhibits high activity (1.54 A mgPt –1 and 1.60 mA cmPt –2) and stability after 1,000 cycles, but also achieves CO* oxidation at a lower potential (first peak 0.762 V, Fig. 6f). Furthermore, the I-T curve in low concentration methanol solution indicates that the nest will effectively enrich methanol, improving the ability to resist concentration polarization (Fig. 6g). Therefore, creating a rigid carbon shell on the nanoparticle surface to protect and regulate the reaction center is a key direction for the development of electrocatalysts in the future. 4.2 Modifying microenvironment with diverse functional groups The charge center and functional groups with different properties around the catalytic center show disruptive effects on the selectivity and stability of the reaction [129]. In order to weaken the hydrogen evolution side reaction during the CO2RR process, we constructed –NH2 near the Bi site (named as Bi-NHS) to promote the adsorption, fixation, and activation of CO2, as well as reducing the activation energy of OCHO* intermediation (Fig. 7 a), achieving the Faradic efficiency for HCOO− appears basically unchanged around 90% in a wide range of potentials of −0.66 to −1.06 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7b) [130]. Similarity, Liu et al. [131] introduced amino functional groups in the microenvironment of Ni-N4/C to improve the adsorption energy of CO2 and COOH* (Fig. 7c), achieving current density exceeding 500 mA cm−2 at the membrane electrode level, and Faraday efficiency of nearly 90% for CO generation (Fig. 7d). In terms of electrocatalytic cycling at noble metal sites, Xie group [132] explored the charge interaction between -SO3H or –NH2 and Pt sites, which stabilized the top layer of atoms in the Pt NPs in acid-ORR process. Especially, the effect of improving corrosion-resistance ability is more conspicuous, when amino group is innovated to modify the micro-environment of Pt NPs. Recently, Wei group [133] report a blocking strategy to protect Pt NPs from toxic effects of sulfonic acid groups for boosting the performance of electrocatalysts in the MEA, through the ring-structured cyclohexanol modification of micro-environment (Fig. 7e). The hydroxyl oxygen of cyclohexanol is connected with sulfonic acid of Nafion through coordination interaction, which avoids the problem of forming stable adsorption between sulfonic acid group and Pt surface and reducing the density of electron cloud of Pt site. Shown in Fig. 7(f), the cyclohexanol-Nafion-Pt/C exhibits maximum power density (1.804 W cm−2), ∼1.4 times higher than that of Nafion-Pt/C (1.318 W cm−2). Surprisingly, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (Fig. 7g) shows the modification of peripheral organic structures plays a positive role in promoting charge and mass transfer. This work indicates that the modification of organic peripheral structures will not necessarily hinder the electron transfer process in electrochemical reaction systems. 4.3 The unique characterization method of micro-environment For illustrating the relationship between reactants and active centers under the existence of peripheral structures, the effluence-curve of O2 detected by mass spectrometer (MS) from NCM ⊂ Pt/C (a nest structure by pyrolysis of polyaniline at low temperature) at the switching from the flow of O2 to Ar and the cyan shadow region means the added amount of physically adsorbed O2 (the amount of physically adsorbed O2 on Pt/C and NCM ⊂ Pt/C are 2.1 and 6.6 mL g−1, respectively), shown in Fig. 8 (a) [134]. And then, the sample was heated from − 78 °C to room temperature with a thermal conduction detector (TCD) monitoring the H2 consumption, which reacted with the chemically adsorbed oxygen on the Pt NPs surface. Compared with commercial Pt/C, the Oad/Pts ratio of NCM ⊂ Pt/C is ∼3, slightly higher than the stoichiometry of the oxygen monolayer chemisorption on Pt surface (Oad/Pts = 2) [135], the extra part in region β will be assigned to additional chemisorbed O2 brought about by the porous NCM nest (Fig. 8b), which is also observed in the XPS O 1 s spectrum. Benefiting from the special enrich-O2 function of nest-type NCM, the NCM ⊂ Pt/C represents a TOF value (0.68 atom−1 s−1, Fig. 8c), about three times higher than that of commercial Pt/C, and fulfills the DOE target, perfectly. As mentioned above, the Pt NPs will serve as ORR center, and the NCM nest as the surrounding coordination system to capture oxygen for the reaction center. The higher concentration of O2 in the NCM nest will increase the collision probability between oxygen molecules and the Pt site, thereby boosting ORR kinetics at the cathode of proton membrane fuel cells (Fig. 8d). The above results provide a visual representation method for researchers to further monitor the changes of reactant environment under the influence of peripheral structures. Under DMFCs operating conditions, the mixed potential generated at the cathode due to methanol crossover is an important factor affecting the power density of the entire cell [136]. In addition to developing proton membranes that are resistant to crossover [137], designing cathode catalysts reasonably to ensure that O2 will come into contact with the Pt center and methanol is difficult to achieve, is also an effective means. The key to achieving the above idea is to reveal the influence of peripheral structure on mass transfer in electrochemical process. Sung group [138] synthesized calix[4]arene thiol derivative modification as a reaction probe, proving that large molecules can pass through thin peripheral shell, thus not affecting the transport of small gas molecules (Fig. 8e). In future work, molecular probes may be combined with spectroscopic methods to characterize the impact of peripheral structures on mass transfer, deeply. 5 Summary and outlook This review summarizes the leading-edge strategy on electrocatalysts with multi-hierarchy design, including active sites, high-energy support, and peripheral structure, for key small molecule conversion reactions in the hydrogen-energy economy. How to resolve the problems of high Gibbs free energy, slow kinetics and a sequence of by-products in the process of electrocatalysis is discussed emphatically. Numerous studies have shown that developing a single site from the perspective of morphology and heteroatom doping is no longer sufficient to address the issues arising from industrial applications. Ordering, rationalizing, and customizing the design of multi-hierarchy structures may be an effective way to break through this bottleneck. Although remarkable progress has been obtained in designing electrocatalysts with multi-level structures, researches remain in breaking ice stages and there are still many questions for further exploration, including: (1) How will support more accurately regulate the electronic state of active center? At present, by comparing the Feimi levels between active centers and support, we have achieved controllable control over the direction of electron transfer, but precisely controlling how much electron transfer is a challenge. In terms of ORR, it is not that the more electrons obtained on the Pt surface, the more favorable the catalysis is. (2) How will the peripheral structure of the active center be precisely synthesized? To ensure conductivity, the peripheral structure is usually formed through the pyrolysis of periodic organic component. High temperature treatment will break the strong regularity of MOFs and COFs, resulting in uneven pore size and thickness of peripheral frameworks. (3) How will electrocatalysts with support regulation and peripheral structure modification be industrialized for production? It is a strategy similar to building blocks to first synthesize high-energy carriers, then load active site, and finally modify the peripheral framework, with considerable theoretical research value. Complex processes and long production cycles make this approach unsuitable for large-scale production and commercial applications. High throughput screening may provide an effective way to accurately design the strong interaction between active site and support for specific reactions, realizing controllable electron transfer. Self-assembling conductive polymers or MOFs will provide a choice for precise peripheral structural design of electrocatalysts. Additionally, the coordination between materials synthesis center and reactors during the catalyst produce process may achieve efficient assembly of multi-level structures, and mechanochemical synthesis is also a feasible approach for large-scale and low-cost production of complex catalysts. The cross integration of multiple disciplines as well as the introduction of cutting-edge production and characterization methods will significantly promote the multi-level design process of catalysts, accelerating the development of customized method to solve industrial catalytic challenges. Chenjia Liang is, currently, pursuing for a doctor's degree at Nanjing University under the guidance by Professor Weiping Ding. His research interests focus on the novel design of electrocatalyst in mesoscale. Rurong Liu is currently a postgraduate student of School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University. Her supervisor is Professor Weiping Ding. At present, she focuses on the researches of high-energy mechanochemistry for electrocatalysts design. Ruiyao Zhao, received bachelor of science in Central South University in 2022, is currently pursuing a postgraduate degree in Nanjing University. Her research interests involve surface state regulation for methanol oxidation and hydrogen evolution reaction. Xiaoxia Hou is currently an instrument manager and Ph.D. student at the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University. She received her master’s degree from Nanjing University in 2015. Her research interests include the design of multi-level ordering structure for PEMFCs. Teng Chen is currently a post-doctor of School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University. He received his Ph.D. (2019) from Nanjing University with Profs. Yi Chen and Weiping Ding. His research interests involve catalytic materials in mesoscale for oxygen reduction reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction and ethanol oxidation reaction. Weiping Ding received his bachelor’s and doctor’s degrees from the Department of Chemistry, Nanjing University. He has engaged in postdoctoral research in the National Laboratory of Solid Microstructure, Department of Physics, Nanjing University, as well as researched in the Department of Chemical Engineering, University of California at Berkeley, and the Department of Chemistry and Biology, Harvard University, successively. He is currently a professor in the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University and director of the Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry. In recent years, his advocacy, about “Meso Catalysis” research, has achieved fruitful innovative results in hydrogenation, oxidation, acid catalysis, fuel cell catalysts, and electrocatalysis, which are being transferred to industrial applications.

coredata.dc:description: Under the new energy resource structure, electrocatalysts are key materials for the development of proton membrane fuel cells, electrolysis of aquatic hydrogen devices, and carbon dioxide reduction equipment, to address energy shortages and even environmental pollution issues. Although controlling the morphology or doping with heteroatoms for catalyst active centers have accelerated the reaction rate, it is difficult to solve the problems of multiple by-products, and poor stability of catalytic sites. From this, it will be seen that single regulation of metal active centers is difficult to comprehensively solve application problems. Orderly assembly and coordination of catalyst multi-hierarchy structures at the mesoscale above the nanometer level probably be more reasonable strategies, and numerous studies in thermal catalysis have supported this viewpoint. This article reviews the multi-hierarchy design of electrocatalyst active centers, high-energy supports, and peripheral structures in recent years, providing unconventional inspiration about electrocatalyst creation, which perhaps serves as a simple tutorial of electrocatalysis exploration for abecedarian.
